conclusion: Determine the velocity v1 of the particle when it reaches the collection device on the positive x-axis.
The particle is emitted from the source S located at a distance d = 1.2 m above the origin O in the presence of a uniform magnetic field directed into the paper.
Understand the motion of charged particles in a magnetic field.
When a charged particle moves in a magnetic field, it experiences a magnetic force perpendicular to both its velocity and the magnetic field direction.
This force causes the particle to move in a circular path.
The radius r of the circular path is given by r = mv/|q|B.
Here, v is the velocity of the particle, m is its mass, q is its charge, and B is the magnetic field strength.
Determine the required conditions for the particle to reach the collection device.
The particle must be emitted at an angle such that its trajectory intersects the x-axis.
The angle θ at which the particle is emitted determines the initial velocity components: vx = v cos θ and vy = v sin θ.
Calculate the radius of curvature using q/m = 2 x 10^6 C/kg and B = 5 x 10^-3 T, resulting in r = v/10^4.
Determine the emission angle.
The particle must be emitted at an angle such that it reaches the collection device. The angle given is θ = 48.5°, where sin 48.5° = 0.75.
Calculate the velocity v.
The vertical distance d = 1.2 m corresponds to the vertical component of the circular motion.
The particle travels a quarter of the circle to reach the x-axis.
The vertical component of the velocity is vy = v sin θ = v x 0.75.
The radius r must satisfy the condition r = d/sin θ = 1.2/0.75 = 1.6 m.
Equating the two expressions for r: v/10^4 = 1.6.
Solving for v: v = 1.6 x 10^4 = 16000 m/s.
The particle velocity v1 when it reaches the collection device is 16000 m/s.
